{{about|the 1981 film|the 2009 remake|My Bloody Valentine 3D}} {{Infobox film | name = My Bloody Valentine | image = My bloody valentineposter.jpg | caption = Theatrical poster | director = [[George Mihalka]] | producer = {{plainlist| *John Dunning *André Link *Stephen Miller }} | story = Stephen Miller | screenplay = [[John Beaird]] | starring = {{plainlist| *Paul Kelman *[[Lori Hallier]] *[[Neil Affleck]] *[[Don Francks]] *[[Cynthia Dale]] *[[Alf Humphreys]] *[[Keith Knight (actor)|Keith Knight]] *[[Patricia Hamilton]] }} | music = [[Paul Zaza]] | cinematography = Rodney Gibbons | editing = {{plainlist| *Gérald Vansier *Rit Wallis }} | studio = {{plainlist| *[[Telefilm Canada|Canadian Film Development Corporation]] *Secret Film Company }} | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1981|2|11}} | runtime = 90 minutes{{sfn|Muir|2012|p=199}} | country = Canada | language = English | budget = $2.3 million<ref name=cbp>{{cite web|url=http://www.capebretonpost.com/living/classic-horror-film-was-shot-in-sydney-mines-19997/|work=[[Cape Breton Post]]|location=Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia|title=Classic horror film was shot in Sydney Mines|author=Jala, David|date=February 13, 2017|accessdate=September 21, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171103233213/http://www.capebretonpost.com/living/classic-horror-film-was-shot-in-sydney-mines-19997/|archivedate=November 3, 2017}}</ref> | gross = $5.7 million<ref name=bom/> }} '''''My Bloody Valentine''''' is a 1981 Canadian [[slasher film]] directed by [[George Mihalka]] and written by John Beaird, starring Paul Kelman, [[Lori Hallier]], and [[Neil Affleck]]. The film tells the story of a group of young adults who decide to throw a [[Valentine's Day]] party only to incur the vengeful wrath of an assailant in mining gear who begins a killing spree.
Conceived and produced entirely over the course of around a year,<ref name=bl/> the film was shot on location in [[Sydney Mines]], [[Nova Scotia]], Canada, in the fall of 1980. It was released theatrically in North America beginning in February 1981, coinciding with the Valentine's holiday.
''My Bloody Valentine'' faced notable [[censorship]], having a total of nine minutes cut by the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] due to the amount of violence and gore. Though co-producer Dunning confirmed that the excised footage still existed, attempts to release it proved difficult as [[Paramount Pictures]] refused to offer an uncut version. In 2009, [[Lionsgate]] subsequently acquired DVD rights to the film and released a DVD with three minutes of additional footage restored. The same year, Lionsgate released a [[My Bloody Valentine 3D|remake]] of the film.
==Plot== Inside a mine shaft, a female miner takes off her gear in front of another miner. When the woman performs a striptease, the miner pushes her onto a mining pickaxe, killing her.
Mayor Hanniger of mining town Valentine Bluffs reinstates the traditional Valentine's Day dance, which has been suspended for twenty years. The dances stopped after an accident in which two supervisors left several miners in the mines to attend the dance. Because they forgot to check [[methane]] gas levels, there was an explosion that trapped the miners. Harry Warden, the only survivor, resorted to [[cannibalism]] to survive and became insane. He murdered the two supervisors who left them there, and vowed further attacks if the Valentine's Day Dance ever occurred again. Warden was placed into an asylum and the accident was forgotten, so the dance resumed. A group of young residents are excited about the dance: Gretchen, Dave, Hollis, Patty, Sylvia, Howard, Mike, John, Tommy, and Harriet. Sarah, Axel, and the mayor's son T.J. are involved in a tense love triangle.
Mayor Hanniger and the town's police chief Jake Newby receive an anonymous box of Valentine chocolates containing a human heart, and a note warning that murders will begin if the dance proceeds. That evening, resident Mabel is murdered by a mining-geared killer, and her heart removed. Newby publicly reports that she died of a heart attack to prevent a panic. He contacts the mental institution where Harry Warden was incarcerated, but they have no record of him. Hanniger and Newby cancel the dance but the town's youngsters decide to hold their own party at the mine. A bartender warns them against it but is killed by the miner.
At the party, the miner brutally kills Dave and Sylvia. Newby rushes into the mines with police to rescue the remaining teenagers. The miner impales a large drill into Mike and Harriet, and shoots a nail gun into Hollis's head. Horrified, Howard flees. The remaining four try to climb to the top with a ladder, but discover a dead beheaded Howard.
While finding their way out, Axel and Patty are killed by the miner. The miner chases T.J. and Sarah and a fight ensues. The miner is revealed to be Axel, who faked his demise. A flashback shows that Axel's father was one of the supervisors. As a child, Axel witnessed Harry Warden murdering his father, which traumatized him. The tunnel begins to collapse from the fight, and traps Axel while Newby and the police arrive to rescue T.J. and Sarah. It is revealed that Harry Warden had died five years earlier. T.J. and Sarah hear a rescuer shout that Axel is alive and rush back to the scene. Sarah sees an insane Axel freeing himself from the debris by amputating his trapped arm. He runs deeper into the mine shouting threats to murder everyone in town, and mumbling about Sarah being his “bloody valentine.” The film ends with a maniacal laugh being heard.

==Production== ===Development=== Director George Mihalka, on the strength of his earlier movie ''Pick-Up Summer'', was approached by Cinepix Productions, headed by André Link and John Dunning with a two-movie contract. Mihalka was asked to direct a horror-slasher story, presented to Dunning by Stephen Miller in mid-1980, and, after Mihalka agreed to direct, John Beaird was bought in to write the screenplay.<ref name=mihalka2005>{{Cite web|url=http://www.terrortrap.com/interviews/georgemihalka/|title=My Bloody Memories: An Interview with George Mihalka |date=June 2005|work=The Terror Trap |accessdate=July 16, 2016}}</ref>
The film was originally entitled ''The Secret''; however, the producers decided to change it to ''My Bloody Valentine'', so to overtly reference the holiday serial killer trend{{Sfn|Blake|2013|p=116}} with which the slasher genre was becoming increasingly popular, through films such as ''[[Black Christmas (1974 film)|Black Christmas]]'' (1974), ''[[Halloween (1978 film)|Halloween]]'' (1978) and ''[[Friday the 13th (1980 film)|Friday the 13th]]'' (1980).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.trulydisturbing.com/2013/02/13/day-history-bloody-valentine-1981/|title=This day in History: MY BLOODY VALENTINE|first=Laura |last=Mooney |date=February 13, 2013 |work=Truly Disturbing |accessdate=July 16, 2016}}</ref> At the time, the slasher sub-genre had seen further commercial success with the releases of ''[[Prom Night (1980 film)|Prom Night]]'' and ''[[Terror Train]]'' (both 1980).{{sfn|Leeder|2018|p=65}}
===Filming=== Shooting on ''My Bloody Valentine'' began in September 1980, taking place around the Princess Colliery Mine in Sydney Mines, Nova Scotia,{{Sfn|Pike|2012|p=186}} which had closed in 1975.{{Sfn|Rockoff|2011|p=106}} Filming completed in November 1980.{{Sfn|Rockoff|2011|p=106}} The budget was approximately $2.3 million.<ref name=cbp/> Two mines were considered for the setting, the other in [[Glace Bay, Nova Scotia]]. The production company decided on the Sydney Mines location due to "the exterior [being] a dreary, cold and dusty area [with] no other buildings around it so it looked like it was totally in the middle of nowhere."<ref name=mihalka2005 />
Upon arrival at the town for principal photography, the crew found that the townspeople, unbeknownst to them, had redecorated the mine so to make it more presentable, thus destroying the dark atmosphere that had convinced the production company to base the film there. The cast therefore spent a few days staying in Sydney Mines, encouraged by the director to get a feel for the small-town location.
Mihalka has said since making the movie that the most difficult element of ''My Bloody Valentine'' was filming in the mines. Located {{convert|2700|ft|m}} underground, filming in the mine was a lengthy process, as, due to limited space in the elevators, it would take an hour to assemble the cast and crew underground. Also, due to the methane levels, lighting had to be carefully planned as the number of bulbs that could be safely utilised was limited.<ref name=mihalka2005 /> Prior to the production's arrival to the mine, the owners cleaned up the location significantly, leaving it described as a "clean and colourful [[Disneyland]]-like set."<ref name=cbp/> This resulted in the production team spending an estimated $30,000 to paint portions of the mine to achieve a darker atmosphere, akin to how it had appeared in its original state.{{sfn|Rockoff|2011|p=106}} Producer Dunning referred to the shoot as "horrendous."{{Sfn|Rockoff|2011|p=106}}
==Release== ===Box office=== ''My Bloody Valentine'' grossed [[US dollar|US]]$5,672,031 at the United States box office upon its February 11, 1981 release.<ref name=bom>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=mybloodyvalentine.htm|work=Box Office Mojo|title=My Bloody Valentine (1981)|accessdate=December 28, 2016}}</ref> Though the U.S. gross exceeded the film's $2.3 million budget, it was considered a box-office disappointment by Paramount Pictures, returning a "derisory sum of $2.6 million."{{sfn|Nowell|2011|p=231}} This profit amounted to less than one-third of Paramount's ''Friday the 13th'', released the year before.{{sfn|Nowell|2011|p=231}}
===Critical response=== ====Contemporaneous==== Upon its release, ''My Bloody Valentine'' received numerous reviews criticizing it for its depiction of violence and gore. Bruce Bailey of the ''[[Montreal Gazette]]'' noted the film as having an "awkward script," adding: "All that's really notable about ''My Bloody Valentine'' is that it gives you more than the usual m.p.g.p.{{em dash}}murders per gallon of popcorn."<ref>{{cite news|author=Bailey, Bruce|date=February 14, 1981|work=[[Montreal Gazette]]|location=Montreal, Quebec|p=105|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23907127/the_gazette/|via=Newspapers.com|title='Valentine' lacks essential heart}} {{open access}}</ref> Tom Buckley of ''[[The New York Times]]'' echoed a similar sentiment, writing: "''My Bloody Valentine'' probably won't make you shiver with fright, but it's almost certain to make you squirm, first with irritation and then with revulsion."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9E03EED6143BF931A25751C0A967948260|work=The New York Times|first=Tom|last=Buckley|date=February 12, 1981|accessdate=December 29, 2016|title='My Bloody Valentine'}}</ref> The ''[[Detroit Free Press]]''{{'}}s Jack Mathews conversely complimented the film on delivering "on its title promise by bucketfuls," adding: "There's nothing subtle about ''My Bloody Valentine''. A pickax to the belly, a 10-penny nail through the forehead, a granite drill through the back. There are some passing attempts at comic relief, but most of the yuks are inadvertent."<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Detroit Free Press]]|location=Detroit, Michigan|title=One bad shock deserves another|author=Mathews, Jack|p=8D|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23906922/detroit_free_press/|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}}</ref> Ernest Leogrande of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' noted the film as bearing similarity to other slasher films of the time, but conceded: "Movies like this are designed to make you jump, scream, hide your eyes, hug your date and talk with glee about what bad taste the movie makers are capable of. ''My Bloody Valentine'' does all that."<ref>{{cite news|author=Leogrande, Ernest|date=February 11, 1981|work=[[New York Daily News]]|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23909973/daily_news/|title=So what became of chocolate hearts?|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}}</ref>
Several reviewers were highly critical of the film's partial financing by the [[Telefilm Canada|Canadian Film Development Corporation]], which used taxed income from Canadian provinces to help fund its production: Among them were John Dodd of the ''[[Edmonton Journal]]'', who lambasted the film as a "rip off" of ''Halloween'' (1978), adding: "All this perverted gore is brought to you thanks to the financial help of the Canadian Film Development Corp. which uses your own tax money to help greedy, talentless producers make a killing, you should pardon the expression."<ref>{{cite news|date=February 16, 1981|work=[[Edmonton Journal]]|location=Edmonton, Alberta|title='I couldn't take it anymore'|author=Dodd, John|p=D8|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23907586/edmonton_journal/|via=Newspapers.com}} {{open access}}</ref> [[Gene Siskel]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' also noted the corporation's financing in his review, in which he awarded the film one out of four stars, deeming it a "dismal and depressing horror film," and "another entry in that most depressing of film genres, the mad-slasher-with-a-knife."<ref>{{cite news|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author-link=Gene Siskel|author=Siskel, Gene|p=4|date=February 17, 1981|title='Dogs of War' loses its bite in the second half|location=Chicago, Illinois|via=Newspapers.com|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23906615/chicago_tribune/}} {{open access}}</ref>
Ed Blank of the ''[[Pittsburgh Press]]'' faulted the film's cinematography and mine setting, writing that its "novelty, for the worse as it happens, is that the principal setting is a coal mine where most of the male characters work. Shooting scenes in the mine, brightened only by the miners' hats, permits Mihalka to play without a full deck. You can't tell what's going on."<ref>{{cite news|p=A-5|work=[[Pittsburgh Press]]|location=Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23907357/the_pittsburgh_press/|via=Newspapers.com|author=Blank, Ed|title='Bloody Valentine' A Drag}} {{open access}}</ref> Dan Scapperotti of ''[[Cinefantastique]]'', alternately praised the film's cinematography, writing: "[it] is beautifully photographed, and the utilization of the mine creates powerful imagery."<ref>{{cite journal|work=Cinefantastique|first=Dan|last=Scapperotti|title=My Bloody Valentine|page=48|volume=11|number=1|year=1981}}</ref>
Writing for ''[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|The Atlanta Constitution]]'', Richard Zoglin noted that the film "floats along effortlessly in the current flood of schlock-horror films unleashed by John Carpenter's ''Halloween''. But it is more restrained — even tasteful — than most. The camera averts its eyes from much of the blood and gore, and women are treated somewhat better than usual (that is, they are generally allowed to keep their clothes on before being dispatched)." While praising the film for constraining the amount of violence shown, Zoglin criticized the characters and the plot for being "uninteresting" and "predictable."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22935030/the_atlanta_constitution/|title='Valentine' Slickly Produced But Just A Routine Shocker|last=Zoglin|first=Richard|date=February 17, 1981|work=The Atlanta Constitution|access-date=August 18, 2018}}</ref> Linda Gross of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' panned the film for being "too convoluted, too derivative and, oddly, too ambitious to properly coagulate into the kind of [[exploitation film|exploitation movie]] that it tries to be."<ref name=gross>{{cite news|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|location=Los Angeles, California|title='Bloody Valentine' Is Heartless Fare|date=February 16, 1981|p=2|via=Newspapers.com|author=Gross, Linda|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/23906457/the_los_angeles_times/}} {{open access}}</ref> However, she conceded that the film's cinematography is "sharp" and the musical score "portentous."<ref name=gross/>
====Modern assessment==== Contemporary [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] shows the film has a 47% approval rating, with an average rating of 4.8/10.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/my_bloody_valentine/ |title=My Bloody Valentine (1981) |work=Rotten Tomatoes |accessdate= July 16, 2016}}</ref>
In a March 30, 2007 issue of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', the film was ranked 17 in a list of guilty pleasures, listed among such films as ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)|Dawn of the Dead]]'' and ''[[Escape from New York]]'', and called "the most criminally underappreciated of the [[slasher film|slasher]] genre." Popular filmmaker [[Quentin Tarantino]] called it his all-time favorite slasher film.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1206985,00.html | work=Entertainment Weekly | author=Nashawaty, Chris | title='House' Mates: Tarantino and Rodriguez talk Grindhouse| date=June 23, 2006|accessdate=September 20, 2018}}</ref> In a retrospective assessment, film historian Adam Rockoff wrote that the film was "easily one of the best and most polished slasher films."{{Sfn|Rockoff|2011|p=107}}
In another retrospective assessment by scholar Jim Harper in his book ''Legacy of Blood: A Comprehensive Guide to Slasher Movies'', he notes that the film distinguishes itself from other slashers by moving outside the "typical teen based scenario," instead focusing on a group of twenty-something adults in a [[working class]] community, and relying on a notable "atmosphere dread."{{Sfn|Harper|2004|p=128}}
===Censorship=== ''My Bloody Valentine'' was significantly censored in North America upon its theatrical release.<ref name=bl>{{cite av media|title=Bloodlust: My Bloody Valentine and the Rise of the Slasher Film|year=2009|people=Rockoff, Adam; Mihalka, George; Link, André|publisher=Lionsgate|medium=documentary|format=DVD}}</ref> For the [[Motion Picture Association of America]] (MPAA) to award the movie with an R-rating, cuts were requested to every death sequence in the film; producer Dunning said the film was essentially "cut to ribbons" in order to achieve an R-rating.{{Sfn|Rockoff|2011|p=106}} Even after cutting the film to match the requirements made by the MPAA, it was again returned with an X-rating and further cuts were demanded. Stills of the trimmed footage were published in ''[[Fangoria]]'' magazine whilst the film was still in production, though the sequences were excised from the theatrical version;<ref name=barton>{{cite web|date=December 5, 2009|accessdate=March 13, 2018|author=Barton, Steve|title=My Bloody Valentine (1981) (Blu-ray)|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/reviews/14686/my-bloody-valentine-1981-blu-ray/|work=[[Dread Central]]}}</ref> even today the complete uncut version has not been released (though a 2009 DVD and Blu-ray release by Lionsgate reinstated three minutes of excised footage).<ref name=bl/> The standard North American theatrical cut of the film ran approximately 90 minutes.{{sfn|Muir|2012|p=199}} In the United Kingdom, the film was passed for theatrical release by the [[British Board of Film Classification]] (BBFC) on March 30, 1981; according to the BBFC catalogue, this version ran at 90 minutes and 55 seconds.<ref>{{cite web|work=British Board of Film Classification|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/my-bloody-valentine-1970-1|title=My Bloody Valentine (1981)|accessdate=March 13, 2018}}</ref>
There are two reasons that are frequently attributed to the extreme cutting of the film. It has been suggested that Paramount Pictures was keen to remove the offending footage due to the backlash they had received from releasing ''Friday the 13th'' the previous year. The second reason, that Mihalka attributes, is that the movie was cut due to the [[murder of John Lennon]] in December 1980, stating that there was a major backlash against movie violence in the wake of his death.<ref name=mihalka2005 />
====Restoration efforts==== {{See also|#Home media}} An uncensored cut of ''My Bloody Valentine'' remained unavailable to the public for nearly thirty years after its original theatrical release.<ref name=uncut/> When Paramount released the film on DVD in North America for the first time in 2002, the studio claimed that the purported "missing" footage did not exist.<ref name=barton/>
In 2008, [[Lionsgate]] acquired the rights to the film after producing a [[My Bloody Valentine 3D|feature film remake]], and in the process, acquired excised footage never-before seen in the standard theatrical cut of the film.<ref name=barton/> In January 2009, Lionsgate and Paramount co-released an unrated [[Region 1 DVD|Region 1]] "Special Edition" DVD featuring this footage.<ref name=uncut/> This DVD allows viewers the option to watch the standard R-rated version of the film, as well as an uncensored version in which excised violent footage is reinstated. Despite this, three scenes play in their unrated form regardless of which version is being viewed: the flashbacks of Axel's father's death, and Harry Warden with the arm.<ref name=uncut/> Commenting on the release, director Mihalka said: "[with this DVD] we have it back to 80% of the image back and 95% of the impact back."<ref name=gmtalks>{{cite web|work=ComingSoon.net|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/horror/news/712261-excl-george-mihalka-talks-my-bloody-valentine-uncut#eyAPvvJUtPTYceTm.99|title=EXCL: George Mihalka Talks My Bloody Valentine Uncut|author=Turek, Ryan|date=January 17, 2009|accessdate=March 12, 2018}}</ref>
The 2009 "Special Edition" DVD reinstates approximately two-and-a-half minutes of previously-unreleased footage back into the film, which contradicts an earlier claim by director Mihalka that it had been trimmed by 8–9 minutes.<ref name=dvdtalk09>{{cite web|work=DVD Talk|url=https://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/35922/my-bloody-valentine-special-edition-1981/|title=My Bloody Valentine: Special Edition (1981)|date=January 9, 2009|author=McGaughy, Cameron|accessdate=March 13, 2018}}</ref> It has been argued that the so-called uncut DVD still has some sequences missing, particularly the double-impalement of Mike and Harriet which the director recalls filming. It is thought that the remaining footage appears to be composed of expository scenes, such as dialogue and other non-violence related material. This is given credence by the fact that Mihalka gave his seal of approval to this release, and a written introduction by him precedes the beginning of the special edition DVD, stating that this version was the way that the film was meant to be seen.<ref name=bl/>
===Home media=== ''My Bloody Valentine'' was released to both [[VHS|videotape]] and [[LaserDisc]] in the 1980s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lddb.com/laserdisc/23182/LV1447/My-Bloody-Valentine-(1981) | title='LaserDisc Database'|publisher=LaserDisc Database |accessdate=July 16, 2016}}</ref>
The film made its [[DVD]] debut on September 3, 2002 from Paramount Home Video;<ref name=2002dvd>{{cite av media|publisher=Paramount Home Video|year=2002|title=My Bloody Valentine|orig-year=1981|format=DVD|asin= B000069I04}}</ref> this was a standard widescreen release of the theatrical cut, and it contained no bonus materials.<ref name=2002dvd/> The same disc was re-issued as a DVD double feature with ''[[April Fool's Day (1986 film)|April Fool's Day]]'' (1986; also a Paramount title) in March 2008.<ref>{{cite av media|publisher=Paramount Home Video|year=2002|title=My Bloody Valentine / April Fool's Day|format=DVD|asin= B0017CW5TE}}</ref>
On January 13, 2009, a "Special Edition" DVD version of the film was released in North America, coinciding with the theatrical release of the remake.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Paper (magazine)|Paper]]|url=http://www.papermag.com/my-bloody-valentine-special-edition-dvd-1425508601.html|title=My Bloody Valentine Special Edition DVD|date=January 11, 2009|author=''Paper'' Magazine Staff|accessdate=March 13, 2018}}</ref> This version integrates the cut footage back into the film and features two featurettes and optional introductory sequences to the previously missing murder sequences.<ref name=uncut>{{cite web|work=[[Crave Online|ComingSoon.net]]|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/horror/news/712045-my-bloody-valentine-uncut-deleted-scenes|title=My Bloody Valentine Uncut: Deleted Scenes!|author=Turek, Ryan|date=December 30, 2008|accessdate=March 13, 2018}}</ref> Two featurettes are also included. Director Mihalka, cast members Lori Hallier, Neil Affleck, Helene Udy, and Carl Marotte, composer Paul Zaza and make-up artists Thomas Burman and [[Ken Diaz]] are all involved.<ref name=2009dvd>{{cite av media|title=My Bloody Valentine|format=DVD|publisher=Lionsgate & Paramount Home Video|year=2009|orig-year=1981|asin=B001KZN2IQ|series=Special Edition}}</ref>
A [[Blu-ray]] was released on November 24, 2009 from Lionsgate, on loan from Paramount. The disc contained the same bonus materials as the "Special Edition" DVD released in January 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/movies/My-Bloody-Valentine-Blu-ray/6868/|work=Blu-ray.com|title=My Bloody Valentine|accessdate=February 9, 2017}}</ref> The Blu-ray is now out of print.
==Legacy and remake== On January 16, 2009, shortly after the uncut version of the film was released in [[Canada]], a remake titled ''[[My Bloody Valentine 3D]]'' was released in theaters.{{sfn|Roche|2014|p=10}}

The '''National Curriculum for England''' was first introduced by the [[Education Reform Act 1988|Education Reform Act of 1988]]. At the time of its introduction the legislation applied to both England and Wales. However, education later became a devolved matter for the Welsh government. The current statutory National Curriculum dates from 2014 at which point it was introduced to most year groups across primary and secondary education. Some elements were introduced in September 2015. The National Curriculum sets out the content matter which must be taught in a number of subjects in "local authority–maintained schools".{{efn|That does not include independent schools and state-funded academies – although in practice many such schools do follow the National Curriculum.}} ==Aims== There are two main aims presented in the statutory documentation for the National Curriculum, stating: # The national curriculum provides pupils with an introduction to the essential knowledge they need to be educated citizens. It introduces pupils to the best that has been thought and said, and helps engender an appreciation of human creativity and achievement. # The national curriculum is just one element in the education of every child. There is time and space in the school day and in each week, term and year to range beyond the national curriculum specifications. The national curriculum provides an outline of core knowledge around which teachers can develop exciting and stimulating lessons to promote the development of pupils’ knowledge, understanding and skills as part of the wider school curriculum.{{cite web|title=National curriculum in England: framework for key stages 1 to 4|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/national-curriculum-in-england-framework-for-key-stages-1-to-4/the-national-curriculum-in-england-framework-for-key-stages-1-to-4|website=GOV.UK|publisher=Department for Education|accessdate=27 July 2015}} These aims set out to support the statutory duties of schools to offer a curriculum which is balanced and broadly based and which promotes the spiritual, moral, cultural, mental and physical development of pupils at the school and of society, while preparing pupils at the school for the opportunities, responsibilities and experiences of later life, as set out in the [[Education Act 2002]]. ==Structure== The National Curriculum, as released most recently in 2014, is set out for all year groups for pupils aged between 5 and 16. Within these ages, the curriculum is structured into four [[Key Stage]]s, for each of which a prescribed list of subjects must be taught. text-align:left" | [[Music education|Music]] | [[Image:Yes check.svg|20px]]|| [[Image:Yes check.svg|20px]] || [[Image:Yes check.svg|20px]] || |- | style="background:white; text-align:left" | [[Physical Education]] | [[Image:Yes check.svg|20px]]|| [[Image:Yes check.svg|20px]] || [[Image:Yes check.svg|20px]] || [[Image:Yes check.svg|20px]] |- |} For each of the statutory curriculum subjects, the Secretary of State for Education is required to set out a Programme of Study which outlines the content and matters which must be taught in those subjects at the relevant Key Stages.{{cite web|title=Education Act 2002|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2002/32/part/6|website=GOV.UK|publisher=H M Government|accessdate=27 July 2015}} The most recently-published National Curriculum was introduced into schools in September 2014. ===Other entitlements=== In addition, children in all Key Stages must be provided with a curriculum of [[Religious Education]], and for pupils in Key Stages 3 and 4 a curriculum of Sex and Relationships Education must also be provided. At Key Stage 4, although some subjects are not compulsory for all students, provision must be made to allow all students to access the arts (comprising art and design, music, dance, drama and media arts), design and technology, the humanities (comprising geography and history) and a modern foreign language. ==History== ===Callaghan's Great Debate=== In a 1976 speech at [[Ruskin College]], Prime Minister [[James Callaghan]] launched what became known as the "Great Debate". The speech has been called "revolutionary" in the context of its time,[https://www.theguardian.com/education/2001/oct/16/schools.uk Callaghan's Ruskin College speech about education 25 years ago seemed revolutionary. Today, many of the issues are familiar. That's because we still haven't solved them], Will Woodward, October 2001 and that it "lit a flare that has illuminated education reform ever since".[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2006/oct/17/education.schools 30 years on, Callaghan's words resonate, [[Andrew Adonis]], 2006 The speech intended to stimulate wide debate on the purpose of education in the UK:
These are proper subjects for discussion and debate. And it should be a rational debate based on the facts... It is not my intention to become enmeshed in such problems as whether there should be a basic curriculum with universal standards - although I am inclined to think there should be... The goals of our education, from nursery school through to adult education, are clear enough. They are to equip children to the best of their ability for a lively, constructive, place in society, and also to fit them to do a job of work. Not one or the other but both... Both of the basic purposes of education require the same essential tools. These are basic literacy, basic numaracy, the understanding of how to live and work together, respect for others, respect for the individual. This means requiring certain basic knowledge, and skills and reasoning ability. It means developing lively inquiring minds and an appetite for further knowledge that will last a lifetime. It means mitigating as far as possible the disadvantages that may be suffered through poor home conditions or physical or mental handicap. Are we aiming in the right direction in these matters?[http://www.educationengland.org.uk/documents/speeches/1976ruskin.html 'A rational debate based on the facts']; James Callaghan, Ruskin College Oxford, 18 October 1976
===1988 Education Reform Act=== {{main|Education Reform Act 1988}} The first statutory National Curriculum was introduced by the [[Education Reform Act 1988]] by [[Kenneth Baker, Baron Baker of Dorking|Kenneth Baker]].{{cite web|last1=Gillard|first1=Derek|title=History of Education in England (Chapter 8)|url=http://www.educationengland.org.uk/history/chapter08.html|website=Education in England|accessdate=27 July 2015}} The Programmes of Study were drafted and published in 1988 and 1989, with the first teaching of some elements of the new curriculum beginning in September 1989. ===1994-95 Shephard reforms=== Under [[Gillian Shephard]]'s tenure as Education Secretary, a review of the National Curriculum was launched in 1994, led by [[Ronald Dearing, Baron Dearing|Ron Dearing]]. Its objective was to find ways to 'slim down' the over-detailed curriculum. The final report set out the need to reduce the volume of statutory content, particularly at lower key stages, as well as recommending changes to methods of [[National Curriculum assessment|assessment]].{{cite web|last1=Dearing|first1=Ron|title=Dearing Review, 1994|url=http://www.educationengland.org.uk/documents/dearing1994/dearing1994.html|website=Education in England|publisher=Derek Gillard|accessdate=27 July 2015}} Consequently, an updated National Curriculum was published in 1995 which saw a considerable reduction in the content of the curriculum and a simplification in line with Dearing's recommendations. ===1997-99 Blunkett reforms=== When a new Labour government took office in 1997, its focus on English and Maths led to a decision to disapply the statutory Programmes of Study for the foundation subjects from September 1998, to allow schools to spend more time teaching literacy and numeracy.{{cite news|title=English schools told to go back to basics|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/46975.stm|accessdate=27 July 2015|work=BBC News website|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=13 Jan 1998}} The Secretary of State, [[David Blunkett]] later announced another overhaul of the National Curriculum, particularly at primary level, to reduce the content in foundation subjects allowing more time to be spent on the core subjects of English, Maths and Science.{{cite news|title=National Curriculum faces overhaul|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/93921.stm|accessdate=27 July 2015|work=BBC News website|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=15 May 1998}} A new National Curriculum was published in 1999, for first teaching in September 2000.{{cite news|title=Curriculum to go online|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/517750.stm|accessdate=27 July 2015|work=BBC News website|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=15 Nov 1999}} ===2007-08 Balls reforms=== Further changes were announced by [[Ed Balls]] in 2007 for the statutory curriculum for Key Stages 3 and 4, which again focussed on removing some content from the documentation, while also adding some additional element, with the intended aim of additional flexibility for schools.{{cite news|title=Curriculum to be 'more flexible'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/6293164.stm|accessdate=27 July 2015|work=BBC News website|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=12 July 2007}} These changes were introduced in September 2008, and were swiftly followed by proposed changes to the primary curriculum, based on a review to be led by Jim Rose. The review proposed replacing the 10 statutory subjects in Key Stages 1 and 2 with 6 broader 'areas of learning', such as "understanding English, communication and languages" and "human, social and environmental understanding".{{cite news|title=Primary School subjects overhaul|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/7770469.stm|accessdate=27 July 2015|work=BBC News website|agency=BBC|publisher=BBC|date=8 Dec 2008}} However, following the change of government in 2010, the plans for this change - proposed to begin in September 2011 - were abandoned,{{cite web|title=Rose Review officially abandoned|url=https://education.scholastic.co.uk/content/11405|website=Scholastic.co.uk|publisher=Scholastic|accessdate=27 July 2015}} with schools advised to continue to follow the 2000 curriculum pending review. ===2012-14 Gove reforms=== Following his appointment as Education Secretary in 2010, [[Michael Gove]] commissioned an expert review panel to report on a framework for a new National Curriculum. The review was led by Tim Oates of [[University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate|Cambridge Assessment]], and reported in December 2011. It suggested significant changes to the structure of the National Curriculum, including dividing Key Stage 2 into two shorter (two-year) phases.{{cite book|title=The Framework for the National Curriculum. A report by the Expert Panel for the National Curriculum review|date=Dec 2011|publisher=Department for Education|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/framework-for-the-national-curriculum-a-report-by-the-expert-panel-for-the-national-curriculum-review|accessdate=27 July 2015}} In 2013, the government produced a draft National Curriculum, followed by a final version in September 2013, for first teaching in September 2014. Due to the short timescales for introduction, the curriculum was introduced only for certain subjects and year groups in 2014, with the core subjects in Years 2 and 6 (the final years of Key Stages 1 and 2) only becoming statutory in September 2015, to allow time for the introduction of new testing arrangements at the end of the Key Stages. Similarly, core subjects at Key Stage 4 are to be introduced on a year-by-year basis starting in September 2015 for English and Maths, and September 2016 for Science.{{cite web|title=The national curriculum for England to be taught in all local authority-maintained schools.|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/national-curriculum|website=GOV.UK|publisher=H M Government|accessdate=27 July 2015}} ==Further reading== * Stephen Meredith, 2013, The Oratory of James Callaghan: 'We used to think that you could spend your way out of a recession...'; in Andrew Crines & Richard Hayton (eds.), Labour Orators from Aneurin Bevan to Gordon Brown, Manchester University Press, 2013 * {{cite book|last=White|first=John|title=Intelligence, Destiny and Education: The Ideological Roots of Intelligence Testing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QSR-AgAAQBAJ|date=18 April 2006|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-20387-1}} ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Curricula]] [[Category:Education in England]] [[Category:Secondary education in England]]

{{Infobox music festival | image = File:Open.fest.sarajevo.jpg | music_festival_name = OPEN Fest Sarajevo | location = [[Sarajevo]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] | years_active = 2016 – present | dates = January | organiser = | genre = [[liberalism]] | website = {{URL|http://www.openfest.net/}} }} '''OPEN Fest Sarajevo''' is the largest international [[libertarian]] [[festival]] in [[Europe]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.radiosarajevo.ba/metromahala/teme/drugo-izdanje-open-festa-sarajevo-je-domacin-najveceg-festivala-sloboda-u-europi/272120|title=Najava / Vraća se OPEN Fest: Sarajevo ponovo domaćin najvećeg festivala sloboda u Europi|publisher=Radio Sarajevo}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://multi.ba/en/second-open-fest-spans-five-days-draws-thousands-sarajevo/|title=Second Open Fest spans five days and draws thousands|publisher=multi.ba}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://liberal.hr/clanak.php?id=1188|title=Dođite na Open Fest u Sarajevo: Najveći slobodarski festival u Europi|publisher=liberal.hr}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aldeparty.eu/events/individual-members-open-festival-bosnia-and-herzegovina|title=Individual members: OPEN festival in Bosnia and Herzegovina|publisher=aldeparty.eu}}</ref> It is held annually in [[Sarajevo]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://mediareform.rs/open-fest-2017-2/|title=Open Fest 2017. |publisher=mediareform.rs}}</ref> It is dedicated to the promotion of ideas of liberty and human rights. The Festival promotes economic and political freedoms, together with the fundamental rights of the individual. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://visoko.co.ba/otvoren-najveci-evropski-festival-sloboda-open-fest/|title=Otvoren najveći evropski festival sloboda ‘Open fest’|publisher=visoko.co.ba}}</ref> The festival was established by the Multi Group in cooperation with the [[Atlas Network]], [[Students for Liberty]] and the Rising Tide Foundation. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atlasnetwork.org/news/article/second-open-fest-spans-five-days-draws-thousands-in-sarajevo|title=Second Open Fest spans five days and draws thousands in Sarajevo|publisher=atlasnetwork.org}}</ref> The first edition of the festival hosted over 10,000 guests, 50 [[NGO]]'s and 40 international speakers. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://openfest.net/en/|title=About us|publisher=official website}}</ref>
==Format== The festival is organized in January of each year and lasts for 5 days. It hosts a large conference and lecture program that focuses on the promotion of economic and political freedoms. Subjects that are treated include the [[free market]], [[entrepreneurship]], [[cryptocurrency]], [[technology]], [[legalisation of cannabis]], [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivism]] and others. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.klix.ba/vijesti/bih/open-fest-ce-otvoriti-vas-um-od-liberlanda-preko-islama-i-slobode-do-milionera-i-zarade/161019041|title=Open Fest će otvoriti vaš um: Od Liberlanda, preko islama i slobode, do milionera i zarade|publisher=klix.ba}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.oslobodjenje.ba/o2/kultura/knjizevnost/promocije/open-fest-br-2-bice-da-su-ipak-nemiri-u-svedskoj|title=OPEN Fest br. 2: Biće da su ipak nemiri u Švedskoj|publisher=oslobodjenje.ba}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://fbl.ba/u-sarajevu-javna-tribina-o-legalizaciji-marihuane-u-medicinske-svrhe/|title=U Sarajevu javna tribina o legalizaciji marihuane u medicinske svrhe|publisher=fbl.ba}}</ref> The festival also hosts numerous art exhibitions, film screenings, workshops and a rich entertainment program that includes concerts and VIP parties. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.glas.ba/2016/10/19/fena-novost-prvi-evropski-festival-sloboda-krajem-oktobra-u-sarajevu/|title=FENA Novost: Prvi evropski festival sloboda krajem oktobra u Sarajevu|publisher=fena.ba}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atlasnetwork.org/event/multi-second-annual-open-fest-2017|title=Second Annual Open Fest|publisher=atlasnetwork.org}}</ref> Guests and speakers have included [[FreedomWorks]] president and [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] leader [[Matt Kibbe]], [[Bitnation]] founder Susanne Tarkowski Tempelhof, [[Iran]]ian-[[Swedish people|Swedish]] author [[Nima Sanandaji]], [[anarcho-capitalist]] economist and son of [[Milton Friedman]], [[David D. Friedman]], president of the [[University of the Philippines]] [[Alfredo Pascual]], British journalist and research fellow at the [[Institute of Economic Affairs]], [[Christopher Snowden]] and others. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.radiosarajevo.ba/metromahala/teme/drugo-izdanje-open-festa-sarajevo-je-domacin-najveceg-festivala-sloboda-u-europi/272120|title=Najava / Vraća se OPEN Fest: Sarajevo ponovo domaćin najvećeg festivala sloboda u Europi|publisher=Radio Sarajevo}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://openfest.net/en/|title=Speakers|publisher=official website}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.atlasnetwork.org/event/multi-second-annual-open-fest-2017|title=Second Annual Open Fest|publisher=atlasnetwork.org}}</ref>

"Houses From Within") happens over the course of a weekend annually in [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]], in which different buildings, landmarks and private residences open their doors to the general public to offer a free glimpse of architecture in the past and present, with a preview of design for the future. It is one of many [[Doors Open Days|Open House]] events that take place in cities such as [[London]] and [[New York City]], originally started in [[France]] in 1984.
